Personal computer
{{start date and age|1976|4|11}}

[[MOS Technology 6502|MOS 6502]] @ [[megahertz|1 MHz]] 4 [[kilobyte|KB]] standard
expandable to 8 KB or 48 KB using expansion cards
40×24 characters, hardware-implemented scrolling
[[Apple II]]
Apple Computer 1, also known retroactively as theApple I, orApple-1, was released by the Apple Computer Company (nowApple Inc.) in 1976. They were designed andHandicrafthand-builtbySteve Wozniak.Cite newshttp://news.oneindia.in/2006/09/27/co-founder-tells-his-side-of-apple-story-1159346150.htmlCo-founder tells his side of Apple storyReutersSeptember 27, 2006NPR : A Chat with Computing Pioneer Steve WozniakWozniak's friendSteve Jobshad the idea of selling the computer. The Apple I wasApple Inc.Apple's first product, and to finance its creation, Jobs sold his only means of transportation, aVW Microbus,Kelley: Jobs' vision changed the way we work, playand Wozniak sold hisHP-65calculator for $500.Steve Jobs: Steve Wozniak RemembersIt was demonstrated in July 1976 at theHomebrew Computer ClubinPalo Alto, California.cite bookFreibergerPaulPaul FreibergerMichaelSwaineMichael Swaine (author)Fire in the Valley: The Making of the Personal ComputerMcGraw-Hill2nd2000265–267New York, NY0-07-135892-7At a Homebrew meeting in July 1976, Woz gave a demonstration of the Apple 1. Paul Terrell, one of the industries earliest retailers, was in attendance.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: File:Apple 1 Advertisement Oct 1976.jpgthumbleftIntroductory advertisement for the Apple I ComputerOn March 5, 1975 Steve Wozniak attended the first meeting of theHomebrew Computer Clubin Gordon French's garage. He was so inspired that he immediately set to work on what would become the Apple I computer.cite bookWozniakSteveiWoz2006W.W. Norton & Company978-0-393-33043-4150After my first meeting, I started designing the computer that would later be known as the Apple I. It was that inspiring.Wozniak calculated that laying out his design would cost $1,000 and parts would cost another $20 per computer; he hoped to recoup his costs if 50 people bought his design for $40 each. His friendSteve Jobsarranged to sell 50 computers to theByte Shop(a computer store in Mountain View, California) at $500 each. To fulfill the $25,000 order, they obtained $20,000 in parts at30 days netand delivered the finished product in 10 days.cite newshttp://archive.org/stream/byte-magazine-1984-12/1984_12_BYTE_09-13_Communications#page/n461/mode/2upThe Apple Story / Part 1: Early HistoryBYTEDecember 1984October 23, 2013Williams, Gregg; Moore, RobA67interview

The Apple I went on sale in July 1976 at a price ofUSD666.66,cite webhttp://news.cnet.com/1606-2-5937610.htmlVideo: Wozniak: $666.66 seemed like a good ideaNovember 7, 2005CNET NewsFebruary 19, 2009because Wozniak "liked repeating digits" and because of a one-third markup on the $500 wholesale price.Steve WozniakWozniak, Steven: "iWoz", page 180.W. W. Norton, 2006. ISBN 978-0-393-06143-7The first unit produced was used in a high school math class, and donated toLiza Loop's public access computer center.cite journalTurnerDanielMIT Technology ReviewMIT Technology Review5/1/2007http://www.technologyreview.com/hack/407810/hack-the-apple-i/16 April 2015About 200 units were produced and all but 25 were sold during nine or ten months.rwozniak198412Unlike other hobbyist computers of its day, which were sold as kits, the Apple I was a fully assembled circuit board containing about 60+ chips. However, to make a working computer, users still had to add a case, power supply transformers, power switch, ASCII keyboard, and composite video display. An optional board providing a cassette interface for storage was later released at the cost of $72.

The Apple I's built-incomputer terminalcircuitry was distinctive. All one needed was aKeyboard (computing)keyboardand an inexpensivetelevision set. Competing machines such as theAltair 8800generally were programmed with front-mounted toggle switches and used indicator lights (redlight-emitting diodeLEDs, most commonly) for output, and had to be extended with separate hardware to allow connection to a computer terminal or aASR33teletypewriter machine. This made the Apple I an innovative machine for its day. In April 1977 the price was dropped to $475.April 1977 Price List | ApplefritterIt continued to be sold through August 1977, despite the introduction of theApple IIin April 1977, which began shipping in June of that year.Bill of Sale | ApplefritterApple dropped the Apple I from its price list by October 1977, officially discontinuing it.October 1977 Price List | ApplefritterAs Wozniak was the only person who could answer most customer support questions about the computer, the company offered Apple I owners discounts and trade-ins for Apple IIs to persuade them to return their computerscite webhttp://apple2history.org/history/ah04/The Apple II, cont.February 27, 2011Apple II HistoryThese recovered boards were then destroyed by Apple, contributing to their rarity today.cite webhttp://www.apple1notes.com/old_apple/Huston_Stories_files/A1%20Back%20Story.htmThe Huston brothers' Apple-1 Back StoryJune 25, 2013
article.heading: Collectors' item
article.paragraph: File:Apple1innards.jpgthumbrightThe circuit board of a fully assembled Apple IFile:Original 1976 Apple 1 Computer In A Briefcase.JPGthumbOriginal 1976 Apple 1 Computer in a briefcase. From the Sydney Powerhouse Museum collectionFile:Original 1976 Apple 1 Computer PCB.JPGthumbOriginal 1976 Apple 1 Computer PCB From the Sydney Powerhouse Museum collectionAs of 2013, at least 63 Apple I computers have been confirmed to exist. Only six have been verified to be in working condition.

list.listitem: An Apple I reportedly sold for $50,000 USD at auction in 1999.cite webOngJoshAuction of Apple's first computer expected to top $160khttp://www.appleinsider.com/articles/10/11/11/auction_of_apples_first_computer_expected_to_top_160k.htmlApple InsiderJune 16, 2012November 11, 2010

In 2008, the website "Vintage Computing and Gaming" reported that Apple I owner Rick Conte was looking to sell his unit and was "expecting a price in excess of $15,000 US." The site later reported Conte had donated the unit to the Maine Personal Computer Museum in 2009.cite webApple I For Salehttp://www.vintagecomputing.com/index.php/archives/499September 2
A unit was sold in September 2009 for $17,480 on eBay.cite webThe Apple 1 Registryhttp://www.willegal.net/appleii/apple1-originals.htmApple I Mimeo ProjectJune 16, 2012

A unit belonging to early Apple Computer engineers Dick and Cliff Huston was sold on March 23, 2010 for $42,766 on eBay.cite webCalandeJohnAnother very nice Apple-1 sold on ebay yesterdayhttp://apple1computer.blogspot.com/2010/03/another-very-nice-apple-1-sold-on-ebay.htmlJune 16, 2012March 24, 2010

In November 2010, an Apple I sold for 133,250 ($210,000) atChristie'sauction house in London. The high price was likely due to the rare documents and packaging offered in the sale in addition to the computer, including the original packaging (with the return label showing Steve Jobs' parents' address, the original Apple Computer Inc 'headquarters' being their garage), a personally typed and signed letter from Jobs (answering technical questions about the computer), and the original invoice showing 'Steven' as the salesman. The computer was brought toPolytechnic University of Turinwhere it was fixed and used to run theBASICprogramming language.cite webBBC NewsFirst Apple computer fetches £130,000 at auctionhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11825954BBC NewsJune 16, 2012November 23, 2010cite webChristie's Sale 7882 / Lot 65http://www.christies.com/LotFinder/lot_details.aspx?fromChristie'sJune 16, 2012cite webHeaterBrian$211,000 Apple-1 up and running, wants to know what this 'cloud' thing is all abouthttp://www.engadget.com/2011/05/10/211-000-apple-1-up-and-running-wants-to-know-what-this-cloud/engadgetengadget.comJune 16, 2012

On June 15, 2012, a working Apple I was sold at auction bySotheby'sfor a record $374,500, more than double the expected price.cite newsAustinScottOriginal Apple 1 Computer Sells for $374,500 in Auctionhttp://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2012/06/15/original-apple-1-computer-sells-for-374500-in-auction/June 16, 2012The Wall Street JournalJune 15, 2012This unit is on display at theNexon Computer MuseuminJeju City,South Korea.

In October 2012, a non-working Apple I from the estate of former Apple Computer employee Joe Copson was put up for auction by Christie's, but found no bidder who was willing to pay the starting price ofUS$80,000 (50,000).cite webABC Newshttp://abcnews.go.com/blogs/technology/2012/10/rare-apple-1-computer-no-sale-at-christies-auctionRare apple 1 computer no sale at christies auctionOctober 28, 2012Copson's board had previously been listed on eBay in December 2011, with a starting bid of $170,000 and failed to sell. Following the Christie's auction, the board was restored to working condition by computer historian Corey Cohen.cite webiPhone Hackshttp://www.iphonehacks.com/2015/04/rare-apple-1-pops-up-ebay.htmlRare working Apple-1 pops up on eBay with Cassette board accessorySeptember 30, 2015Copson's Apple I was once again listed on eBay, where it sold for US$263,100.03 on April 23, 2015.cite webhttp://www.ebay.com/itm/Early-1976-Apple-1-computer-from-the-garage-of-Steve-Jobs-/271836061695?nmaEarly 1976 Apple-1 computer, from the garage of Steve JobsSeptember 30, 2015

On November 24, 2012, a working Apple I was sold at auction by Auction Team Breker for 400,000 (US$515,000)cite webthe-saleroom.comhttp://www.the-saleroom.com/en-gb/auction-catalogues/auction-team-breker/catalogue-id-2869018/lot-15886115ATG MediaNovember 24, 2012

On May 25, 2013, a functioning 1976 model was sold for a record 516,000 (US$668,000) inCologne.http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/working-apple-1-sells-at-auction-for-record-breaking-671400/Auction Team Breker said "an unnamed Asian client" bought the Apple I. This particular unit has Wozniak's signature. An old business transaction letter from Jobs also was included, as well as the original owner's manual.cite webVintage Apple computer auctioned off for $668,000http://news.yahoo.com/vintage-apple-computer-auctioned-off-668-000-153151365.htmlYahoo NewsMay 25, 2013

On June 24, 2013, an Apple I was listed by Christie's as part of a special on-line only auction lot called, "First Bytes: Iconic Technology From the Twentieth Century". Bidding ran through July 9, 2013. The unit sold for $390,000.cite webFirst Apple Computer Sells for $390,000 in Christie’s Technology Auctionhttp://www.ibtimes.co.uk/articles/488167/20130709/apple-1-computer-sold-auction-online-technology.htmInternational Business TimesJuly 9, 2013cite webApple I auction fails to break 500Khttp://macmint.com/apple-1-auction-fails-to-break-500kMacmintJuly 14, 2013

In November 2013, a working unit speculated to have been part of the original lot of 50 boards delivered to The Byte Shop was listed by Auction Team Breker for 180,000 ($242,820), but failed to sell during the auction. Immediately following the close of bidding, a private collector purchased it for 246,000 ($330,000). This board was marked '01-0046', matching the numbering placed on other units sold to The Byte Shop and included the original operation manuals, software cassettes, and shipping box autographed by Steve Wozniak. The board also bears Wozniak's signature.cite webApple 1 Sold for $330k After Auction Closehttp://www.cultofmac.com/254940/update-apple-1-does-sell-for-330k-after-auction-closeCult of MacMarch 28, 2014

In October 2014, a working, early Apple 1 was sold at auction for $905,000 to theHenry Ford MuseuminDearborn, Michigan. The sale included the keyboard, monitor, cassette decks, and a manual. The auction was run byBonham's.cite webApple-1 computer sold at auction for $905,000http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2014/10/22/apple-1-computer-sold-at-auction-for-905000Fox NewsOctober 22, 2014

On December 13, 2014, a fully functioning, early Apple I was sold at auction for $365,000 by auction houseChristie's. The sale included a keyboard, custom case, original manual, and a check labeled "Purchased July 1976 fromSteve Jobsin his parents' garage inLos Altos, CaliforniaLos Altos".cite webComputer sold by Steve Jobs out of his parents' garage raises $365,000 at auctionhttps://news.yahoo.com/computer-sold-steve-jobs-parents-115801772.htmlYahoo!December 14, 2014

On May 30, 2015, an electronicsrecycling centerin theSilicon Valleyof Northern California, USA, is looking for a woman who dropped off boxes of electronics for recycling and disposal, within which an old Apple I computer was found and turned out to be a collectible item worth $200,000. The computer was inside boxes of electronics that she had cleaned out from her garage after her husband died. The recycling firm sold the Apple I for $200,000 to a private collection, and because the company's practice is to give back to the original owner 50% of the proceeds when an item is sold, they want to split the proceeds with the mystery donor if they can find her.

On September 21, 2015, an Apple I bearing the Byte Shop number 01-0059 was listed by Bonhams Auctions as part of their "History of Science and Technology" auction with a starting bid of US$300,000. The machine was described as, "in near perfect condition." The owner, Tom Romkey, "...only used the Apple-1 once or twice, and ...set it on a shelf, and did not touch it again."cite webLot 77 APPLE-1 COMPUTERhttp://www.bonhams.com/auctions/22964/lot/77/Bonhams Auctions21 September 2015October 1, 2015The machine did not sell.cite webEarly Apple computer fails to sellhttp://www.bbc.com/news/technology-34313005BBC News22 September 2015October 1, 2015

article.heading: Serial numbers
article.paragraph: Both Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak have stated that Apple did not assign serial numbers to the Apple l. Several boards have been found with numbered stickers affixed to them, which appear to be inspection stickers from the PCB manufacturer/assembler. A batch of boards is known to have numbers hand-written in black permanent marker on the back; these usually appear as "01-00##" and anecdotal evidence suggests they are inventory control numbers added by the Byte Shop to the batch Apple sold them. These Byte Shop numbers have often erroneously been described as serial numbers by auction houses and in related press coverage.cite webThe Apple 1 Registryhttp://www.willegal.net/appleii/apple1-originals.htmJune 26, 2013
article.heading: USA Museums displaying an original Apple 1 Computer

list.listitem: American Computer Museumin Bozeman, Montana
Computer History Museumin Mountain View, California

article.heading: Clones and replicas
article.paragraph: Several Apple I clones and replicas have been released in recent years. These are all created by hobbyists and marketed to the hobbyist/collector community. Availability is usually limited to small runs in response to demand.

list.listitem: Replica 1: Created by Vince Briel. A software-compatible clone, produced using modern components, released in 2003 at a price of around $200.replica I the apple I(c) clone, retrieved August 15, 2009replica Iat official Briel computers web site, retrieved August 15, 2008Gagne, KenImage gallery: Building an Apple-1 replica from scratch,Computerworld, 2009-08-14, story with pictures for assembling a Briel replica I from a kit, retrieved August 15, 2009Owad, TomApple I Replica Creation, retrieved August 15, 2009
A-One: Created by Frank Achatz, also using modern components.Achatz Electronics, retrieved July 29, 2013, archived May 13, 2012

Obtronix Apple I reproduction: Created by Steve Gabaly, using original components or equivalents thereof. Sold through eBay.Vectronics Apple World: Obtronix Apple I Reproduction, retrieved July 8, 2013
Mimeo 1: Created by Mike Willegal. A hardware kit designed to replicate a real Apple I as accurately possible. Buyers are expected to assemble the kits themselves.Mimeo 1 kit, retrieved July 8, 2013

Newton 1: Created by Michael Ng. A hardware kit similar to the Mimeo 1, and sold through eBay.Apple 1 Replica (Newton 1) Running Test Program, retrieved July 8, 2013Newton 1 replica photos by creator Michael Ng, retrieved July 8, 2013
Brain Board, a plug in firmware board for the Apple II that, with the optional "Wozanium Pack" program, can emulate a functional Apple-1.The Brain Board with Wozanium Pack, retrieved February 2, 2014

article.heading: Emulation

list.listitem: Apple 1js, a web-based Apple I emulator written in JavaScript.
Multi Emulator Super SystemMESS, a multi-system emulator able to emulate the Apple I.
OpenEmulator, an accurate emulator of the Apple I, the ACI (Apple Cassette Interface) and CFFA1 expansion card.
Pom1, an open source Apple I emulator for Microsoft Windows, Arch Linux and Android devices.Pom1 Apple 1 Emulator, retrieved July 17, 2013
Apple 1 Emulator, an emulator for theSAM Couphome computer.Apple 1 Emulator - SAM Coup, retrieved July 17, 2013
CocoaPom, a Java-based emulator with a Cocoa front end for Macintosh.CocoaPom Apple 1 Emulator, retrieved July 17, 2013
Sim6502, an Apple I emulator for Macintosh.Sim6502 Apple I emulatorretrieved July 17, 2013
